You need to enable JavaScript to run this app.
Suggested Citation: Global Fortification Data Exchange. Dashboard: Country Fortification. Accessed dd/month/yyyy. [http://www.fortificationdata.org.]
Chart: Total Food Availability

Chart showing total annual food supply available for human
                                                            consumption by country (Use this chart to identify total
                                                            annual food availability of maize flour, oil, salt, rice, or
                                                            wheat flour in a country)

Chart: Quantity and Proportion of Industrially Processed
                                                            Food Vehicles

Chart showing the total quantity and proportion of each food
                                                            vehicle that is industrially processed by country

Chart: Context for Fortified Food Vehicle Coverage in the
                                                            Population

Chart of the proportion of a country’s population reported to
                                                            consume a fortified food vehicle, compared to the population
                                                            consuming that food (fortified or not), compared to the
                                                            entire population

Chart: Quantity and Proportion
                                                            ofIndustrially Processed Foods by
                                                            Year

Chartdisplaying the total quantity and proportion
                                                            of each industrially processed food vehicle in a country by
                                                            year
Map: Presence of external and import monitoring protocols

Whether countries with mandatory fortification legislation have the applicable protocols to monitor the domestic
                                                            production (external monitoring) or importation (import monitoring) of fortified foods. The presence of a
                                                            monitoring protocol indicates that a country has identified procedures to carry out external and/or import
                                                            monitoring of food fortification. If a country lacks an external and/or import monitoring protocol, it would
                                                            suggest that a basic foundational document for the implementation of food fortification programs is
                                                            missing.

Map: Quantity and Proportion of Food Vehicle that is
                                                            Fortified

Map of the total quantity and proportion of a food vehicle
                                                            that is fortified
Map: Food Intake and Availability

Map counting the number of nutrients required in food
                                                            vehicles by country (Use this map to identify by country how
                                                            many nutrients are required in mandatory or voluntary
                                                            standards for maize flour, oil, salt, rice, and/or wheat
                                                            flour)

Map: Population Coverage of Fortified Food Vehicle in
                                                            Countries with Mandatory or Voluntary Fortification

Map of the proportion of a country’s population with access
                                                            to the fortified food vehicle
Chart: Year When Food Fortification Mandated

Chart of the number of countries with mandatory food
                                                            fortification over time (Use this chart to identify when a
                                                            country first passed mandatory fortification of maize flour,
                                                            oil, salt, rice, and/or wheat flour)

Plot: Fortification Legislation Scope in Countries with
                                                            Mandatory Fortification

Plot displaying the scope of fortification legislation, which
                                                            includes information on whether all food vehicle types or a
                                                            subset are required to be fortified and whether mandatory
                                                            legislation requires food vehicles of different
                                                            origins/destinations and intended uses to be fortified
Map: Fortification Legislation

Map of legal status of food fortification by country (Use
                                                            this map to identify which countries have mandatory and
                                                            voluntary legislation for the fortification of maize flour,
                                                            oil, rice, salt, and/or wheat flour)
Map: Number of Food Vehicles with Standards

Map counting the number of food vehicles with fortification
                                                            standards by country (Use this map to identify by country
                                                            how many of the following foods have mandatory or voluntary
                                                            standards: maize flour, oil, salt, rice, and/or wheat
                                                            flour)
Map: Count of Nutrients in Standards

Map counting the number of nutrients required in food
                                                            vehicles by country (Use this map to identify by country how
                                                            many nutrients are required in mandatory or voluntary
                                                            standards for maize flour, oil, salt, rice, and/or wheat
                                                            flour)

Map: Nutrient Levels in Fortification Standards
                                                            [mid-range or average]

Map displaying the amount of each nutrient required in food
                                                            vehicles by country (Use this map to identify by country
                                                            nutrient levels required in mandatory or voluntary standards
                                                            for maize flour, oil, salt, rice, or wheat flour)

Map: Availability of Data on Health Status Before and
                                                            After Mandatory Fortification

The purpose of mandatory food fortification is to improve health outcomes in a population. Health improvements
                                                            can be measured in changes in blood biomarkers and/or changes in functional outcomes that are caused by a
                                                            deficiency in a nutrient. This visualization presents the number of countries that have data or studies
                                                            comparing health status before and after mandatory fortification.

GFDx Analysis: Alignment of national fortification standards with WHO guidelines (nutrient
                                                            compounds)

Nutrients can be added in fortification as different chemical forms (compounds). This visualization compares the
                                                            nutrient compounds specified in national fortification standards to those recommended in WHO guidelines.
GFDx Analysis: Comparison of national fortification standards with WHO guidelines (nutrient levels)

Nutrient amounts (or levels) added in fortification should contribute meaningfully to dietary intake. This
                                                            visualization compares nutrient levels specified in national fortification standards to those recommended in WHO
                                                            guidelines. Results from this analysis should be used as a starting point for policymakers to discuss whether
                                                            national fortification requirements are as safe and effective as possible.

GFDx Analysis: Potential nutrient intake under ideal (unadjusted) and real-life (adjusted for program
                                                            implementation data, where available) scenarios

This visualization calculates the potential intake of nutrients included in fortification standards based on food
                                                            intake/availability information. Data is presented under the ideal scenario that all foodcanandhasbeen
                                                            fortified, as well as real-life scenario that adjusts data for the proportion of food that can be fortified
                                                            (i.e., is industrially milled) and the proportion of food thathasbeen fortified (i.e., compliance,
                                                            quality, or
                                                            expert opinion data), if this data is available.

This dashboard presents a summary of fortification data for each country in which we’ve collected micronutrient metrics and food standards. The charts and statistics below help compose a user-friendly visualization for anyone interested in visualizing key metrics such as fortification monitoring protocols, quality, compliance, coverage, and fortification standards. Our data is easily filtered by the micronutrient data map or drop-down filter function in the top-right section of the dashboard.

Nutrients in maize flour fortification standards are described in the first section. Here you will also find maize flour fortification coverage, fortification opportunity, and food availability based on the population coverage of maize flour for each country.

Oil fortification standards are in the next section, where fortification quality and compliance help us understand how much oil is fortified. Nutrients found in oil include Vitamin D and Vitamin A, while the fortification opportunity of industrial processing indicates the feasibility to fortify such food. The population coverage directly affects the expected benefits from fortification.

Rice fortification standards can also be visualized on this dashboard. The fortification legislation status may not be available for all countries, but many will list what nutrients can be found in rice standards. If rice fortification coverage is available, one can conceptualize the fortification opportunity based on its proportion of industrially processed rice and availability.

Another important food is salt. The legislation scope for salt includes many types of salt that must be fortified. The presence of monitoring protocols helps external & import production observations become clear. Nutrients in salt fortification may include iodine in milligrams per kilogram of salt.

Finally, we have wheat flour as a final category of food fortification on our data visualization dashboard. Voluntary fortification shows a variety of nutrients in wheat flour with some quality and compliance statistics available. The opportunity for wheat flour in these countries may be determinant on the proportion of wheat flour industrially processed.
Please feel free to explore the data and interact with the Global Food Fortification Exchange dashboard. We aim to provide global micronutrient data in an easy-to-understand format for all.

This dashboard includes data for the countries listed below:AlgeriaAngolaBeninBotswanaBurkina FasoBurundiCabo VerdeCameroonCentral African RepublicChadComorosCongoCote d’IvoireDemocratic Republic of the CongoDjiboutiEgyptEquatorial GuineaEritreaEthiopiaGabonGhanaGuineaGuinea-BissauKenyaLesothoLiberiaLibyaMadagascarMalawiMaliMauritaniaMauritiusMoroccoMozambiqueNamibiaNigerNigeriaRwandaSao Tome and PrincipeSenegalSeychellesSierra LeoneSomaliaSouth AfricaSouth SudanSudanTogoTunisiaUgandaTanzaniaZambiaZimbabweGambiaEswatiniAntigua and BarbudaArgentinaBahamasBarbadosBelizeBoliviaBrazilCanadaChileColombiaCosta RicaCubaDominicaDominican RepublicEcuadorEl SalvadorGrenadaGuatemalaGuyanaHaitiHondurasJamaicaMexicoNicaraguaPanamaParaguayPeruSaint Kitts and NevisSaint LuciaSaint Vincent and the GrenadinesSurinameTrinidad and TobagoUnited States of AmericaUruguayVenezuelaAfghanistanArmeniaAzerbaijanBahrainBangladeshBhutanBrunei DarussalamCambodiaCyprusGeorgiaIndiaIndonesiaIraqIsraelJapanJordanKazakhstanKuwaitKyrgyzstanLao PDRLebanonMalaysiaMaldivesMongoliaMyanmarNepalOmanPakistanPhilippinesQatarSaudi ArabiaSingaporeSri LankaSyriaTajikistanThailandTimor-LesteTurkeyTurkmenistanUnited Arab EmiratesUzbekistanViet NamYemenIranNorth KoreaSouth KoreaPalestineChinaAlbaniaAndorraAustriaBelarusBelgiumBosnia and HerzegovinaBulgariaCroatiaCzech RepublicDenmarkEstoniaFinlandFranceGermanyGreeceHungaryIcelandIrelandItalyLatviaLiechtensteinLithuaniaLuxembourgMaltaMonacoMontenegroNetherlandsNorwayPolandPortugalMoldovaRomaniaRussiaSan MarinoSerbiaSlovakiaSloveniaSpainSwedenSwitzerlandUkraineVatican CityMacedoniaUnited KingdomKosovoAustraliaFijiKiribatiMarshall IslandsMicronesiaNauruNew ZealandPalauPapua New GuineaSamoaSolomon IslandsTongaTuvaluVanuatu

Afghanistan
Last updated: 30-Jan-2025
Maize flour
Oil

This document provides the legal justification for mandatory fortification, and for implementing and monitoring fortification of the specified foods.
Does the legislation or standard document indicate there is mandatory fortification of at least one food vehicle fit for human consumption?

In some cases, fortification may not apply to all types of the food or food uses. The document should be clear about defining what types of food fortification applies to so that industry is clear what should be fortified.
Foods may be produced locally, imported, and/or exported. Exported foods typically must follow the regulations of the importing country, so countries producing food for export may choose to exempt exported foods from fortification. The legislation should be clear where fortification does or does not apply.
Does the document clearly specify how the fortification legislation should be applied to foods, depending on whether all or a subset of foods must be fortified?

Wheat flour"(12) The Factory shall fortify all the flour products with vitamin and minerals (in accordance with the ANSA Standards and the instructions of Ministry of Public Health), without any exception."[1]Oil(1)	All the producers of fortified edible oil are obliged to produce fortified edible oil in accordance with the set rules and national standards by the ANSA (Afghanistan National Standards Agency) and all guidance of the Ministry of Public Health.[1]Salt1- Salt iodization: It is the addition of specified quantities of  iodine to the salt for human and animal use[2]
All types (no exceptions)
All types (no exceptions)
All types (no exceptions)
All types (no exceptions)
All types (no exceptions)

In some cases, fortification may not apply to all types of the food or food uses. The document should be clear about defining what types of food fortification applies to so that industry is clear what should be fortified.
Foods may be produced locally, imported, and/or exported. Exported foods typically must follow the regulations of the importing country, so countries producing food for export may choose to exempt exported foods from fortification. The legislation should be clear where fortification does or does not apply.
Does the document clearly specify how the fortification legislation should be applied to foods, depending on whether foods that are domestically produced, imported, or exported must be fortified?

Wheat flour"(12) The Factory shall fortify all the flour products with vitamin and minerals (in accordance with the ANSA Standards and the instructions of Ministry of Public Health), without any exception."[1]Oil(1)	All the producers of fortified edible oil are obliged to produce fortified edible oil in accordance with the set rules and national standards by the ANSA (Afghanistan National Standards Agency) and all guidance of the Ministry of Public Health.  2.	The imported Edible oil must be fortified with vitamin A& D according to the national standard.[1]SaltArticle 7: Persons, have the duty to obtain a license for the purpose of production and distribution of iodized salt[2]
Domestically producedImportedExports
Domestically producedImportedExports
Domestically producedImportedExports
Domestically producedImportedExports
Domestically producedImportedExports

In some cases, fortification may not apply to all types of the food or food uses. The document should be clear about defining what types of food fortification applies to so that industry is clear what should be fortified.
Foods may be produced locally, imported, and/or exported. Exported foods typically must follow the regulations of the importing country, so countries producing food for export may choose to exempt exported foods from fortification. The legislation should be clear where fortification does or does not apply.

Does the document clearly specify how the fortification legislation should be applied to foods, depending on whether food designated for household use, processed food, animal feed, or donated food must be fortified?

Wheat flour"(12) The Factory shall fortify all the flour products with vitamin and minerals (in accordance with the ANSA Standards and the instructions of Ministry of Public Health), without any exception."[1]Oil(1)	All the producers of fortified edible oil are obliged to produce fortified edible oil in accordance with the set rules and national standards by the ANSA (Afghanistan National Standards Agency) and all guidance of the Ministry of Public Health.  2.	The imported Edible oil must be fortified with vitamin A& D according to the national standard.[1]Salt1- Salt iodization: It is the addition of specified quantities of  iodine to the salt for human and animal use[2]

If a significant proportion of the national supply of salt is used in animal feed, consider expanding the legislation scope to include a requirement for animal feed to use fortified salt. the fortified salt is important for the health and productivity of the animals themselves and can also help increase nutrient intake in humans through consumption of animal products.

If the country is projected to be a main recipient of donated oil (e.g. via external emergency food assistance programs) or utilizes oil in institutional feeding programs (e.g. school feeding and social safety net programs), consider expanding the legislation scope to include a requirement for donated oil or oil used in institutional feeding programs to be fortified.

If a significant proportion of the national supply of salt is used in animal feed, consider expanding the legislation scope to include a requirement for animal feed to use fortified salt. the fortified salt is important for the health and productivity of the animals themselves and can also help increase nutrient intake in humans through consumption of animal products.

If the country is projected to be a main recipient of donated oil (e.g. via external emergency food assistance programs) or utilizes oil in institutional feeding programs (e.g. school feeding and social safety net programs), consider expanding the legislation scope to include a requirement for donated oil or oil used in institutional feeding programs to be fortified.

If a significant proportion of the national supply of salt is used in animal feed, consider expanding the legislation scope to include a requirement for animal feed to use fortified salt. the fortified salt is important for the health and productivity of the animals themselves and can also help increase nutrient intake in humans through consumption of animal products.

If the country is projected to be a main recipient of donated oil (e.g. via external emergency food assistance programs) or utilizes oil in institutional feeding programs (e.g. school feeding and social safety net programs), consider expanding the legislation scope to include a requirement for donated oil or oil used in institutional feeding programs to be fortified.

If a significant proportion of the national supply of salt is used in animal feed, consider expanding the legislation scope to include a requirement for animal feed to use fortified salt. the fortified salt is important for the health and productivity of the animals themselves and can also help increase nutrient intake in humans through consumption of animal products.

If the country is projected to be a main recipient of donated oil (e.g. via external emergency food assistance programs) or utilizes oil in institutional feeding programs (e.g. school feeding and social safety net programs), consider expanding the legislation scope to include a requirement for donated oil or oil used in institutional feeding programs to be fortified.

If a significant proportion of the national supply of salt is used in animal feed, consider expanding the legislation scope to include a requirement for animal feed to use fortified salt. the fortified salt is important for the health and productivity of the animals themselves and can also help increase nutrient intake in humans through consumption of animal products.

If the country is projected to be a main recipient of donated oil (e.g. via external emergency food assistance programs) or utilizes oil in institutional feeding programs (e.g. school feeding and social safety net programs), consider expanding the legislation scope to include a requirement for donated oil or oil used in institutional feeding programs to be fortified.

Policy cohesion - ensuring that that policies or laws in a country do not contradict each other - is important to avoid confusion amongst regulatory actors and industry. Any older policy/law that is replaced by a newer policy/law should include language that repeals the older policy/law.
If there is at least one prior legislation or standard document requiring fortification, does the current legislation or standard document provide repeals or amendments?
Does not specify prior document requiring fortification
Does not specify prior document requiring fortification

Wheat flour"Upon creation (establishment) of fortified food Independent National Board the    National Board of salt iodization which has been publicized in article (5) of Iodine Salt Regulation in formal magazine No (1048) date (06-01-1390) is deemed invalid." (Article 35)[1]

Fortification activities often involve multiple government agencies or ministries. For example, coordination, establishing legislation and standards, and implementing regulatory monitoring control activities may all conducted by separate government agencies. It is important that these different fortification roles are clearly understood by all stakeholders to ensure that the program is implemented efficiently and without gaps.
Is there a document that describes the role in fortification for at least one government agency? What does it state?

Wheat flour"The National Fortified Food Board under the structure this regulation and the iodized salt regulation will undertakes the following duties and responsibilities: 1. The Food Board is the Supreme and highest decision-making body (Authorized Entity) in connection with the issue related to the Fortified foods (including fortified wheat flour and edible oil, and also iodized salt). 2. Coordinating the programs and fortified food practices and activities (including fortified wheat flour and edible oil, and also iodized salt). 3. Preparing of Food Board Annual Report presented to the Ministers Council yearly. 4. Proposals for the revision of the Standards of fortified Foods (in consideration with all country requirements and conditions). 5. Monitor the implementation of this Regulation and the Regulation of iodized salt. 6. Giving necessary and useful advices for the Craftsman(Wheat Flour, Liquid Edible Oils ,Fats and Iodine Salts etc.)" (Article 5)[1]Salt"The national iodization board has the following responsibilities and authorities: 1. Making salt iodization policy and strategy 2. The coordination of salt iodization programs and activities 3. The effective analysis of the universal salt iodization activities 4. Submission of annual report of national salt iodization board to the council of Ministers 5. Reviewing of the standard contained in table (1) as an attachment to this regulation 6. Monitoring of the implementation of these regulations: (Article 6)[3]
Without a clear start date, it will be unclear when fortification and monitoring activities may begin.
Does the legislation or standard document provide effective date or gives grace period for when fortification is to begin (e.g., effective 6 months from signing)?

Wheat flour"1. The importer shall gain the fortified wheat flour import permit and license from the Ministry of Commerce and Industry. And any importer will not have the right to import non-fortified wheat flour with six month after enactment of this regulation." (Article 8)[1]Salt"These  regulations are in force after being published in the official gazette." (Article 30)[3]
Without a standard defining the nutrients and amounts required under fortification, there is no basis to monitor any parameters related to fortification.
Is there a document for the food that states at least one nutrient and nutrient level required in fortification to be present/added to the food at import or production?
There are no WHO recommendations.
Vitamin A
Retinyl palmitate
9 mg/kg
Vitamin D
D3 (cholecalciferol)
0.075 mg/kg
Nutrient levels and compounds inSaltfortification standard in Afghanistan
Iodine
All compounds are WHO recommended
182% of the maximum WHO recommended level
Nutrient levels and compounds inWheat flourfortification standard in Afghanistan

All compounds are WHO recommended

Folate (B9)

For certain nutrients (e.g. iron, zinc), multiple nutrient compounds can be used, and some are preferable for their bioavailability or organoleptic properties, depending on how much of the fortified food is consumed. Specifying the compound is important to ensure that premix providers have all the information they need to procure the correct vitamins and minerals and adhere to the standard.
Is there a document for the food that states at least one fortificant (chemical compound) that may be used (including fortificants that are allowable as options)?
There are no WHO recommendations.

Labeling of nutrients and levels included in a fortified product is important as an initial visual cue to food inspectors and consumers that the product should be fortified. Labelling of manufacturing details, including manufacturer and a batch identifier is important to ensure traceability and ensure action can be taken if product issues should arise.
Is there a document that specifies labeling requirement or provides guidance to indicate a product is fortified? If so, what does it state?

Wheat flour"7. Any Sack (Package) of fortified wheat flour  must include the label (stuck on it)indicating type and the amount of Micronutrients, Manufacturing Company, name of original country, and any other necessary trade specifications, it is good if the text "according to Afghanistan national standard" in local language be written in the label." (Article 8)[1]Salt"The producer must write the following on the packet or the bag of iodized salt: 1. Name of the salt (iodized salt) in readable and clear letters. 2. Name and address of the factory 3. License NO. 4. Net weight in metric units. 5. The iodine compound used 6. Level  of iodine in the salt 7. The chemical matter added (anti hardening and emulsifiers) 8. The date of manufacture  and expiry 9. The packing identification code (batch number)(the repackers must make use of the packing identification code) 10. Directions for storage (this storage must take place in cold dry place away from direct sunlight) 11. The Ministry of Public Health (MoPH) logo 12.  Information about the benefits of the iodized salt." (Article 17)[3]

Fortification monitoring is usually only one responsibility within an inspector’s duties. For sustainability, fortification monitoring should be integrated into an existing regulatory monitoring system.
Is the external monitoring protocol specific to fortification only or does it appear to include fortification as one of the monitoring items in a broader inspection protocol?
There is no external monitoring protocol
There is no external monitoring protocol
Protocols are procedural instructions. If it is not clear which government agency is carrying out the protocol, then there may be no ownership of external monitoring of fortification.
Is there a document that states which government agency is responsible for conducting external monitoring at the production site to ensure compliance with standards and regulations?

Wheat flour"2. Having License from the Environment Protection Agency (EPA)." (Article 7)[1]Salt"1. The department of the quality control of drugs and food material of the Ministry of Public Health must control the implementation standards contained in the table of annex one and also the quality of iodized salt and the duration of its use 2. The Health Laws Enforcement Agency (Directorate) must monitor the implementation of the provisions of these  regulations or other health guidelines of salt iodization 3. The Public Health Nutrition Department of the Ministry of Public Health must monitor technically the production of iodized salt 4. the Environmental Health Department of the Ministry of Public Health from the point of view of sanitation  monitor the salt iodization factory." (Article 24)[3]

If there are several government agencies responsible for external monitoring (or their roles overlap for certain foods), it is essential that each agency’s roles are clearly defined so that there is no confusion and inefficient use of resources.
If two or more government agencies are involved in external monitoring, does the document clarify the roles and responsibilities between different government agencies in external monitoring?
Protocol does not refer to two or more governmental agencies
Protocol does not refer to two or more governmental agencies

These are essential elements of a protocol that should guide a regulatory monitoring inspector in fortification monitoring activities. Some of these activities (e.g. reporting procedures, procedures for noncompliance) may not be specific for fortification, but general regulatory monitoring procedures for any food.
Frequency of inspections

There is no external monitoring protocol

Sample collection protocol, including when to take samples
There is no external monitoring protocol

Wheat flour"The method of drawing representative samples from a warehouse shall be in accordance with Codex Sampling Plans For Prepackaged Foods AQL 6.5 (XOT13), (or Afghanistan Standard equivalent)" (Section 8.1)[5]

These are essential elements of a protocol that should guide a regulatory monitoring inspector in fortification monitoring activities. Some of these activities (e.g. reporting procedures, procedures for noncompliance) may not be specific for fortification, but general regulatory monitoring procedures for any food.

There is no external monitoring protocol

Fortification monitoring is usually only one responsibility within an inspector’s duties. For sustainability, fortification monitoring should be integrated into an existing regulatory monitoring system.
Is the import monitoring protocol specific to fortification only or does it appear to include fortification as one of the monitoring items in a broader inspection protocol?
There is no import monitoring protocol
There is no import monitoring protocol
Protocols are procedural instructions. If it is not clear which government agency is carrying out the protocol, then there may be no ownership of import monitoring of fortification.
Is there a document that states which government agency is responsible for conducting import monitoring at the importation/border site to ensure compliance with standards and regulations?
There is no import monitoring protocol

Wheat flour"1. The importer shall gain the fortified wheat flour import permit and license from the Ministry of Commerce and Industry. And any importer will not have the right to import non-fortified wheat flour with six month after enactment of this regulation." (Article 8)[1]

If there are several government agencies responsible for import monitoring (e.g. if there are multiple border control agencies), it is essential that each agency’s roles are clearly defined so that there is no confusion and inefficient use of resources.
If two or more government agencies are involved in import monitoring, does the document clarify the roles and responsibilities between different government agencies in import monitoring?
Protocol does not refer to two or more governmental agencies
There is no import monitoring protocol

Wheat flour"1. The importer shall gain the fortified wheat flour import permit and license from the Ministry of Commerce and Industry. And any importer will not have the right to import non-fortified wheat flour with six month after enactment of this regulation." (Article 8)[1]

These are essential elements of a protocol that should guide a regulatory monitoring inspector in fortification monitoring activities. Some of these activities (e.g. reporting procedures, procedures for noncompliance) may not be specific for fortification, but general regulatory monitoring procedures for any food.

Industry should be treated with both incentives and penalties to encourage fortification and discourage future non-compliance. Incentives and penalties can take different or several forms (e.g. positive or negative media attention, fines or tax incentives, increased or decreased regulatory scrutiny, etc.) and should be commensurate with the level of risk and the impact of actions (positive or negative) on the intended purpose of fortification.
Is there a document that states incentives to continue fortification, including ensuring compliance?

Non-compliance with regulations should be met with penalties that discourage future non-compliance. These penalties can take different (or several) forms, e.g. fines, increased regulatory monitoring inspections and audits.
Is there a document that outlines penalties for non- compliance?

Wheat flour"First Phase: cash fine (10000AF) Ten thousand Afghani & seizing of the product. Second Phase: cash fine (30000AF) Thirty thousand Afghani. Third Phase: cash fine (100000AF) one hundred thousand Afghani. Fourth phase: suspension of license for one year  Fifth Phase: cancellation license and Introducing the repeated violators to judicial and justice departments" (Article 28)[1]Salt" (1) The producer and distributor of iodized salt if act against these provisions of these regulations will be penalized as follows: 1. For the first time,  receive verbal  warning 2. For the second time,  receive written warning  3. For the third time,  fine of 50000Afs 4. For the fourth time, a fine of 100000Afs5. For the fifth time, the suspension of license for one year. The amounts mentioned in part  (3 & 4) of paragraph (1) of this article are obtained  by the MoPH and deposited in the bank as the receivables of the state." (Article 23)[3]

Inspections and audits can be complemented with laboratory testing of nutrient levels if capacity and resources allow. However, because various analytical assays for measuring nutrient content can provide different values, for consistency it is important to state which assay should be used for a nutrient for consistent results.

Are these specified: analytical assays and the methodologies that are approved to assess the nutrient(s) included in fortification? (e.g., liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry for folic acid, atomic absorption for iron and zinc)?

Salt"The finished product should be tested quantitatively every one or two hours in factory laboratory by titration method or its other quantitative tests to ensure that production of iodized salt is in accordance with standard (30-50ppm) and iodine pump grade should be adjusted to that." (Section 5, Stages of the Process)[4]Wheat flour"Quantitative spectrophotometric method for determination of total iron in wheat flour" (Appendix 1)[5]

The Islamic Republic of Afghanistan. 26/March/2011.4.Afghanistan National Standards Authority.                                                             Food VehiclesChart showing the total quantity and proportion of each food

                                                            PopulationChart of the proportion of a country’s population reported to

                                                            ofIndustrially Processed Foods by
                                                            YearChartdisplaying the total quantity and proportion
                                                            of each industrially processed food vehicle in a country by
                                                            year

Map: Presence of external and import monitoring protocolsWhether countries with mandatory fortification legislation have the applicable protocols to monitor the domestic
                                                            production (external monitoring) or importation (import monitoring) of fortified foods. The presence of a
                                                            monitoring protocol indicates that a country has identified procedures to carry out external and/or import
                                                            monitoring of food fortification. If a country lacks an external and/or import monitoring protocol, it would
                                                            suggest that a basic foundational document for the implementation of food fortification programs is
                                                            missing.

Map: Quantity and Proportion of Food Vehicle that is
                                                            FortifiedMap of the total quantity and proportion of a food vehicle
                                                            that is fortified

Map: Food Intake and AvailabilityMap counting the number of nutrients required in food
                                                            vehicles by country (Use this map to identify by country how
                                                            many nutrients are required in mandatory or voluntary
                                                            standards for maize flour, oil, salt, rice, and/or wheat
                                                            flour)

Map: Population Coverage of Fortified Food Vehicle in
                                                            Countries with Mandatory or Voluntary FortificationMap of the proportion of a country’s population with access
                                                            to the fortified food vehicle

Chart: Year When Food Fortification MandatedChart of the number of countries with mandatory food
                                                            fortification over time (Use this chart to identify when a
                                                            country first passed mandatory fortification of maize flour,
                                                            oil, salt, rice, and/or wheat flour)

Plot: Fortification Legislation Scope in Countries with
                                                            Mandatory FortificationPlot displaying the scope of fortification legislation, which
                                                            includes information on whether all food vehicle types or a
                                                            subset are required to be fortified and whether mandatory
                                                            legislation requires food vehicles of different
                                                            origins/destinations and intended uses to be fortified

Map: Fortification LegislationMap of legal status of food fortification by country (Use
                                                            this map to identify which countries have mandatory and
                                                            voluntary legislation for the fortification of maize flour,
                                                            oil, rice, salt, and/or wheat flour)

Map: Number of Food Vehicles with StandardsMap counting the number of food vehicles with fortification
                                                            standards by country (Use this map to identify by country
                                                            how many of the following foods have mandatory or voluntary

                                                            flour)

Map: Count of Nutrients in StandardsMap counting the number of nutrients required in food
                                                            vehicles by country (Use this map to identify by country how
                                                            many nutrients are required in mandatory or voluntary

                                                            flour)

                                                            [mid-range or average]Map displaying the amount of each nutrient required in food
                                                            vehicles by country (Use this map to identify by country
                                                            nutrient levels required in mandatory or voluntary standards
                                                            for maize flour, oil, salt, rice, or wheat flour)

Map: Availability of Data on Health Status Before and
                                                            After Mandatory FortificationThe purpose of mandatory food fortification is to improve health outcomes in a population. Health improvements
                                                            can be measured in changes in blood biomarkers and/or changes in functional outcomes that are caused by a
                                                            deficiency in a nutrient. This visualization presents the number of countries that have data or studies
                                                            comparing health status before and after mandatory fortification.

GFDx Analysis: Alignment of national fortification standards with WHO guidelines (nutrient
                                                            compounds)Nutrients can be added in fortification as different chemical forms (compounds). This visualization compares the
                                                            nutrient compounds specified in national fortification standards to those recommended in WHO guidelines.

GFDx Analysis: Comparison of national fortification standards with WHO guidelines (nutrient levels)Nutrient amounts (or levels) added in fortification should contribute meaningfully to dietary intake. This
                                                            visualization compares nutrient levels specified in national fortification standards to those recommended in WHO
                                                            guidelines. Results from this analysis should be used as a starting point for policymakers to discuss whether
                                                            national fortification requirements are as safe and effective as possible.

GFDx Analysis: Potential nutrient intake under ideal (unadjusted) and real-life (adjusted for program
                                                            implementation data, where available) scenariosThis visualization calculates the potential intake of nutrients included in fortification standards based on food
                                                            intake/availability information. Data is presented under the ideal scenario that all foodcanandhasbeen
                                                            fortified, as well as real-life scenario that adjusts data for the proportion of food that can be fortified
                                                            (i.e., is industrially milled) and the proportion of food thathasbeen fortified (i.e., compliance,
                                                            quality, or
                                                            expert opinion data), if this data is available.

This dashboard presents a summary of fortification data for each country in which we’ve collected micronutrient metrics and food standards. The charts and statistics below help compose a user-friendly visualization for anyone interested in visualizing key metrics such as fortification monitoring protocols, quality, compliance, coverage, and fortification standards. Our data is easily filtered by the micronutrient data map or drop-down filter function in the top-right section of the dashboard.Nutrients in maize flour fortification standards are described in the first section. Here you will also find maize flour fortification coverage, fortification opportunity, and food availability based on the population coverage of maize flour for each country.Oil fortification standards are in the next section, where fortification quality and compliance help us understand how much oil is fortified. Nutrients found in oil include Vitamin D and Vitamin A, while the fortification opportunity of industrial processing indicates the feasibility to fortify such food. The population coverage directly affects the expected benefits from fortification.Rice fortification standards can also be visualized on this dashboard. The fortification legislation status may not be available for all countries, but many will list what nutrients can be found in rice standards. If rice fortification coverage is available, one can conceptualize the fortification opportunity based on its proportion of industrially processed rice and availability.Another important food is salt. The legislation scope for salt includes many types of salt that must be fortified. The presence of monitoring protocols helps external & import production observations become clear. Nutrients in salt fortification may include iodine in milligrams per kilogram of salt.Finally, we have wheat flour as a final category of food fortification on our data visualization dashboard. Voluntary fortification shows a variety of nutrients in wheat flour with some quality and compliance statistics available. The opportunity for wheat flour in these countries may be determinant on the proportion of wheat flour industrially processed.Please feel free to explore the data and interact with the Global Food Fortification Exchange dashboard. We aim to provide global micronutrient data in an easy-to-understand format for all.This dashboard includes data for the countries listed below:AlgeriaAngolaBeninBotswanaBurkina FasoBurundiCabo VerdeCameroonCentral African RepublicChadComorosCongoCote d’IvoireDemocratic Republic of the CongoDjiboutiEgyptEquatorial GuineaEritreaEthiopiaGabonGhanaGuineaGuinea-BissauKenyaLesothoLiberiaLibyaMadagascarMalawiMaliMauritaniaMauritiusMoroccoMozambiqueNamibiaNigerNigeriaRwandaSao Tome and PrincipeSenegalSeychellesSierra LeoneSomaliaSouth AfricaSouth SudanSudanTogoTunisiaUgandaTanzaniaZambiaZimbabweGambiaEswatiniAntigua and BarbudaArgentinaBahamasBarbadosBelizeBoliviaBrazilCanadaChileColombiaCosta RicaCubaDominicaDominican RepublicEcuadorEl SalvadorGrenadaGuatemalaGuyanaHaitiHondurasJamaicaMexicoNicaraguaPanamaParaguayPeruSaint Kitts and NevisSaint LuciaSaint Vincent and the GrenadinesSurinameTrinidad and TobagoUnited States of AmericaUruguayVenezuelaAfghanistanArmeniaAzerbaijanBahrainBangladeshBhutanBrunei DarussalamCambodiaCyprusGeorgiaIndiaIndonesiaIraqIsraelJapanJordanKazakhstanKuwaitKyrgyzstanLao PDRLebanonMalaysiaMaldivesMongoliaMyanmarNepalOmanPakistanPhilippinesQatarSaudi ArabiaSingaporeSri LankaSyriaTajikistanThailandTimor-LesteTurkeyTurkmenistanUnited Arab EmiratesUzbekistanViet NamYemenIranNorth KoreaSouth KoreaPalestineChinaAlbaniaAndorraAustriaBelarusBelgiumBosnia and HerzegovinaBulgariaCroatiaCzech RepublicDenmarkEstoniaFinlandFranceGermanyGreeceHungaryIcelandIrelandItalyLatviaLiechtensteinLithuaniaLuxembourgMaltaMonacoMontenegroNetherlandsNorwayPolandPortugalMoldovaRomaniaRussiaSan MarinoSerbiaSlovakiaSloveniaSpainSwedenSwitzerlandUkraineVatican CityMacedoniaUnited KingdomKosovoAustraliaFijiKiribatiMarshall IslandsMicronesiaNauruNew ZealandPalauPapua New GuineaSamoaSolomon IslandsTongaTuvaluVanuatu

Next
This dashboard presents a summary of fortification data for each country in which we’ve collected micronutrient metrics and food standards. The charts and statistics below help compose a user-friendly visualization for anyone interested in visualizing key metrics such as fortification monitoring protocols, quality, compliance, coverage, and fortification standards. Our data is easily filtered by the micronutrient data map or drop-down filter function in the top-right section of the dashboard.
Nutrients in maize flour fortification standards are described in the first section. Here you will also find maize flour fortification coverage, fortification opportunity, and food availability based on the population coverage of maize flour for each country.
Oil fortification standards are in the next section, where fortification quality and compliance help us understand how much oil is fortified. Nutrients found in oil include Vitamin D and Vitamin A, while the fortification opportunity of industrial processing indicates the feasibility to fortify such food. The population coverage directly affects the expected benefits from fortification.
Rice fortification standards can also be visualized on this dashboard. The fortification legislation status may not be available for all countries, but many will list what nutrients can be found in rice standards. If rice fortification coverage is available, one can conceptualize the fortification opportunity based on its proportion of industrially processed rice and availability.
Another important food is salt. The legislation scope for salt includes many types of salt that must be fortified. The presence of monitoring protocols helps external & import production observations become clear. Nutrients in salt fortification may include iodine in milligrams per kilogram of salt.
Finally, we have wheat flour as a final category of food fortification on our data visualization dashboard. Voluntary fortification shows a variety of nutrients in wheat flour with some quality and compliance statistics available. The opportunity for wheat flour in these countries may be determinant on the proportion of wheat flour industrially processed.
Please feel free to explore the data and interact with the Global Food Fortification Exchange dashboard. We aim to provide global micronutrient data in an easy-to-understand format for all.
This dashboard includes data for the countries listed below:
